byline.original: By DAVE PHILIPPS and ELIZABETH A. HARRIS
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Patrick McGeehan, Jad Mouawad and Liam Stack from New York; Emma G. Fitzsimmons from Philadelphia; and Sheryl Gay Stolberg from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Though being struck by flying objects is typically not a serious safety concern, it is a common occurrence for train crews.

headline.print_headline: Rock Hurling Is Old Nemesis of Train Crews
headline.main: Rock Hurling Is Old Nemesis of Train Crews

snippet: Though being struck by flying objects is typically not a serious safety concern, it is a common occurrence for train crews.
abstract: Residents of North Philadelphia, site of Amtrak crash that killed eight people and injured more than 200, say broken fences around tracks provide easy access for anyone to hurl rocks, bricks or other projectiles at passing trains; while investigators have not yet determined what caused Amtrak Train 188 to veer off rails, they have raised possibility of flying object striking train.
